Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Transcutaneous Auricular Nerve Stimulation for Pain Reduction After Orthopaedic Trauma Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, 86 participants aged over 18 years undergoing orthopaedic trauma surgery were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: 86 participants aged over 18 years undergoing orthopaedic trauma surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive either active or sham bilateral TAN

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if transcutaneous auricular nerve stimulation (TAN) reduces pain after orthopaedic trauma surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the absolute change in pain 24 hours postoperatively, measured using a 100 mm visual analogue scale (VAS)

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation

Number_Randomised.evidence: From June 22, 2021, to July 7, 2022, 79 participants completed the study

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean reduction in VAS was 19 mm (95% CI: 12–26) in the active TAN group (n=40) compared to 10 mm (95% CI: 3–17) in the sham group (n=39; P=0.023)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included auricular skin irritation in six participants in the active group and two in the sham group
